Civic Duty

Jury Duty Obligations

What to know about serving on a jury

Your Rights

5 rights in this scenario

Your employer cannot punish you, fire you, or threaten you for missing work to serve on a jury. This is a protected civic responsibility. If your employer retaliates, you have legal remedies. Bring your jury summons to your employer to prove your obligation.

Source: Jury Systems Improvement Act (28 U.S.C. ¬ß 1875) and State Laws

Federal courts and most state courts pay jurors a small daily fee. Some employers pay your regular wages during jury duty, but this is not required by law. Compensation varies widely by jurisdiction. Longer trials pay more, though the amounts are typically modest.

üí° This right has state-specific variations. Select a state to see relevant details.

Source: 28 U.S.C. ¬ß 1871 (federal) and State Jury Compensation Laws

If jury duty is being served at a bad time‚Äîyou have a critical work project, vacation booked, or family emergency‚Äîyou can request to reschedule your service to a later date. Courts are often flexible about this. Submit your request promptly with a valid reason; requests made early are more likely to be granted.

Source: State Court Rules and Judicial Discretion

If jury duty would cause genuine financial or personal hardship‚Äîyou're the sole caregiver, you're self-employed and would lose significant income, or you have a medical condition‚Äîyou can petition to be excused. Courts must consider your circumstances. Provide documentation of hardship.

üí° This right has state-specific variations. Select a state to see relevant details.

Source: 28 U.S.C. ¬ß 1869 (federal) and State Hardship Exemption Rules

Responding to a jury summons is a legal obligation. Failure to appear without valid excuse can result in contempt of court charges, fines up to $1,000, or jail time in serious cases. If you cannot serve, respond to the summons and explain your situation. Ignoring a summons is not an option.

Source: 28 U.S.C. ¬ß 1866 and State Court Contempt Laws

Educational Disclaimer: This tool is for educational purposes only and does not constitute legal advice. For specific legal questions, consult a licensed attorney in your jurisdiction.
